title: Alcohol Withdrawal: How to Get Through It
author: Alicia Racelis, PhD

sections.heading: What Is Alcohol Withdrawal?
content: When you drink heavily for a long time and quit suddenly or go "cold turkey," it can bring on a range of symptoms called alcohol withdrawal. Most people go through withdrawal with mild problems. But for others, quitting may lead to serious or even dangerous issues.
Alcohol is an addictive substance that changes the chemicals in your brain and body. Your body can build up a tolerance over time, making you physically dependent on alcohol.
What is alcohol withdrawal syndrome?
This is another name for alcohol withdrawal. Symptoms can start six hours after you quit. If the symptoms do not worsen, you'll feel better in a few days.
As your body readjusts to life without alcohol, you might go through include:
What is delirium tremens (DTs)?
It's a life-threatening but treatable form of alcohol withdrawal. DTs can occur in about 5 out of 100 people who have been drinking heavily for a long period. Symptoms include:
If you or a loved one shows any signs of DTs, get help right away.

sections.heading: When Can Alcohol Withdrawal Symptoms Be Serious?
content: About 1 in 5 people can get serious alcohol withdrawal. It's unclear why, but you're more likely to get symptoms if you:
bullets: Have a history of serious withdrawal symptoms
Have medical conditions such as low platelets (thrombocytopenia), heart disease, gastrointestinal (GI) problems, or respiratory illnesses
Eat a poor diet, with low levels of thiamine (vitamin B1), potassium, or magnesium
Have tried to quit drinking over and over (kindling effect)

sections.heading: After 12 hours.
content: If your withdrawal progresses, you might get hallucinations. But if symptoms worsen, seizures are most likely to strike 12 to 48 hours after you quit.

sections.heading: After two to four days.
content: If your symptoms worsen, you may have a serious form of alcohol withdrawal or delirium tremens. It can take a few weeks to months to heal from DTs.
If you or your loved one shows any serious withdrawal symptoms, get medical help right away.

sections.heading: Home Remedies for Alcohol Withdrawal
content: If you're managing your withdrawal at home, you can take steps to help ease your recovery. Even so, it's best to reach out to your doctor or loved ones for support and guidance. This can help you know what to expect and how to prepare.

Remove temptation. Get rid of any alcohol in your home or ask a friend or family member to do it for you. This includes beer, liquor, wine, or any products made with alcohol, such as rubbing alcohol or vanilla extract.
Stay away from people who may encourage drinking or don't support your decision. This may include "drinking buddies." It'll be easier on your recovery to skip out on alcohol-focused activities.

sections.heading: Build a support system.
content: Tell your family, friends, or others if you plan to quit drinking or are going through a withdrawal. Ask someone you trust to help you challenge negative thoughts. They can help you keep going even if you feel like giving up.
Keep a list of emergency phone numbers on hand. Include the contact info for your doctor, the police, a nearby hospital, and someone you trust.

Take care of yourself. Eat nutritious food, exercise, and get enough sleep . This can help you lessen your mood swings and relax. And if you don't feel hungry, try a multivitamin, or drink a high-electrolyte beverage, such as a sports drink. Take your medication as your doctor directed. Call them if you think you're having a problem.

Stay hydrated and snack smart. Drink plenty of fluids. Drink water, sip on sparkling water , fruit juices, or low-fat milk to stay hydrated. But keep in mind that fruit juice can be high in sugar. Choose foods high in carbohydrates such as pretzels, crackers, or apples to satisfy your cravings.

sections.heading: Consider supplements for alcohol withdrawal.
content: Withdrawal can reduce your appetite and you may not eat as much. This may mean you'll get fewer vitamins in your body. Ask your doctor if you need supplements or extra vitamins. A multivitamin containing vitamin B1 (thiamine), vitamin B9 (folic acid), and vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) can help.
Manage your stress . Do your best to lower stress and control cravings. Add soft lights, comfortable pillows, and blankets to make your room more soothing. You can also try these calming activities:

Keep yourself distracted. If you can't concentrate, try short activities instead. Watch a television show, take a walk, play a video game, or go to the store. You can talk to friends or do whatever you enjoy to stay distracted.
Make a plan in case you relapse. Relapses can happen during recovery, but what's important is how you move forward. Talk with your support person and make a plan to handle relapses ahead of time.
Friends and loved ones can offer support to help you understand why it happened and what you'll do differently. Write down your reasons for quitting. Often revisit this list to renew your resolve.

sections.heading: Medications for Alcohol Withdrawal
content: Medicines can help manage your withdrawal symptoms. If your symptoms get serious, treatment can support your recovery.
Mild alcohol withdrawal. Talk therapy and peer support groups can help you face your drinking problem. Therapy can be a welcoming place for you to meet others going through the same thing.
Medications to ease mild symptoms can include:

Moderate alcohol withdrawal. If your symptoms get more intense, you may get a single dose of chlordiazepoxide or diazepam. But if your withdrawal symptoms don't stop, you may need inpatient treatment.
Serious or complicated alcohol withdrawal. A few people can get serious symptoms. The hospital can monitor your symptoms and other health conditions continuously.
bullets: Long-acting benzodiazepines such as chlordiazepoxide (Librium) or diazepam (Valium) to calm your nerves and lower anxiety
Carbamazepine (Epitol, Tegretol) to control your seizures, if you can't take gabapentin
Gabapentin (Neurontin, Gralise) to quiet your brain activity

sections.heading: Inpatient and Outpatient Therapies for Alcohol Withdrawal
content: Some people may not be able to manage their withdrawal at home. Depending on how serious your symptoms get, a center or hospital can provide treatment.

sections.heading: Inpatient treatment
content: . These hospitals or centers monitor you and help you stay sober long-term. They'll make sure you're hydrated and fix electrolyte and vitamin imbalances. Inpatient programs also provide medical detoxification or "detox" to rid your body of alcohol.

Outpatient treatment. If you've completed detox, you may prefer an outpatient program. You'll visit your doctor or a center during the day, returning home each night. Many times these plans combine therapy, medication, and follow-up visits.

Alcohol withdrawal and hallucinations. You may hallucinate during withdrawal, meaning you could see, hear, smell, taste, or feel things that aren't there. But unlike delirium tremens, you are aware that you're hallucinating. Seek medical help right away if you have alcohol hallucinations.

sections.heading: How to Avoid Alcohol Withdrawal Symptoms
content: The best way to avoid alcohol withdrawal symptoms is to give up drinking. But even cutting down on alcohol helps lower the chances of serious symptoms.

Recovery helps you focus on how to stop drinking. But as an addictive drug, alcohol can cause a chronic medical condition called alcohol use disorder (AUD). Although many people recover, setbacks are common. Getting help early from your loved ones helps prevent relapse.

sections.heading: How to get support
content: . Connecting with people who best understand what you're going through can ease your recovery and help you stick to your resolution.

Think about what you want in a support group. Do you want to meet in person, by video, or via online forums? Find out if they focus on other issues important to you, such as gender, mental health, or something else.
Ask your doctor or therapist about mutual support programs at your local hospital or community center. Or look into support groups, such as:
You can also find help and support at the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Service Administration (SAMHSA) or call the SAMHSA National Helpline at 1-800-662-4357.

When to contact a doctor. See your doctor right away if you or your loved one has seizures, hallucinations, or signs of DTs. These treatable but life-threatening symptoms often need medical care. Call your doctor or get medical help right away.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Alcohol withdrawal is the name for physical and mental symptoms that happen when you suddenly quit heavy drinking. Many people can manage alcohol withdrawal at home. But sometimes, the symptoms can be serious, requiring medical attention.

sections.heading: Alcohol Withdrawal FAQs

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Alcohol withdrawal is the name for physical and mental symptoms that happen when you suddenly quit heavy drinking. Many people can manage alcohol withdrawal at home. But sometimes, the symptoms can be serious, requiring medical attention.

sections.heading: What is delirium tremens (DTs)?
content: Delirium tremens can be life-threatening. With this type of alcohol withdrawal, you may not realize that what you see, hear, feel, or smell isn't real. If you or a loved one has confusion, hallucinations, seizures, or other signs of withdrawal, get medical help right away.
